revision.comment: /* Operators */ Added source for IP - please add your source INTO the article next time, and 11 total were ordered
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} {|{{Infobox aircraft begin |name= AS565 Panther |image= File:No. 488 an AS.565SA Panther of 36 F based at Hyères (3218013326).jpg |caption= A [[French Navy]] Panther }}{{Infobox aircraft type |type= Military utility and armed assault helicopter |national origin=France |manufacturer= [[Aérospatiale]]
[[Eurocopter]]
[[Airbus Helicopters]] |designer= |first flight= 29 February 1984 |introduced= |retired= |status= Operational in production |primary user= [[Brazil]] |more users= France |produced= 1984–present |number built= |unit cost= |developed from= [[Eurocopter AS365 Dauphin]] |variants with their own articles= }} |} The '''Eurocopter AS565 Panther''' is the military version of the [[Eurocopter AS365 Dauphin]] medium-weight multi-purpose twin-engine [[helicopter]]. The Panther is used for a wide range of military roles, including combat assault, fire support, anti-submarine warfare, anti-surface warfare, search and rescue, and medical evacuation (MEDEVAC). ==Development== {{expand section|date=December 2015}} During the 1980s, French aerospace firm [[Aerospatiale]] decided to develop a purpose-built military version of their popular [[Eurocopter AS365 Dauphin]]. The civil SA365 N variant of the Dauphin was used as the starting point for the project; the new rotorcraft was designed to perform utility, [[Anti-tank warfare#Helicopters|anti-tank]], troop-transport, and maritime operations. On 28 February 1984, the military variant prototype, designated as the AS365M and later named Panther, conducted its first flight. A total of three prototypes were built. In May 1986, Aerospatiale formally launched production of the AS365M, at which point the firm anticipated more than 400 Panthers to be sold in the long term.[https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1986/1986%20-%201025.html "Aerospatiale unleashes Panther."] ''Flight International'', 10 May 1986. p. 3. The initial production model, which was initially designated as the AS365 K, was shortly re-designated and became widely known as the AS565 Panther.McGowen 2005, p. 163. Early models were powered by a pair of [[Turbomeca Arriel|Turbomeca Arriel 1M1]] [[turboshaft]] engines; in 1995, [[Eurocopter]] began offering higher powered versions of the Panther that used the new [[Turbomeca Arriel|Turbomeca Arriel 2C]] engine instead.[https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1995/1995%20-%201918.html "More power for Naval Panther."] ''Flight International'', June 1995. p. 21. In February 2016, Airbus Helicopters promised to relocate the global production line for the AS565 Panther to India if it is selected by the [[Indian Navy]] for a proposed utility helicopter acquisition.Perry, Dominic. [https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/singapore-airbus-helicopters-targets-asian-sales-ex-422232/ "SINGAPORE: Airbus Helicopters targets Asian sales expansion."] ''Flight International'', 22 February 2016.Sanjai, P.R. [http://www.livemint.com/Companies/F0D0wYOK77ErwJ4dEIrZxN/Airbus-plans-global-hub-in-India-for-Panther-copters.html "Airbus plans global hub in India for Panther copters."] ''Live Mint'', 15 March 2016. In April 2016, the production rate of the AS565 Panther was announced to have been substantially increased following a switch from a static production line to a takt flow line, as well as a 30 per cent due reduction in component lead times.Perry, Dominic. [https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/airbus-helicopters-advances-panther-mbe-deliveries-424020/ "Airbus Helicopters advances Panther MBe deliveries."] ''Flight International'', 8 April 2016. ==Design== [[File:BMS 005.jpg|thumb|Multiple AS565 Panthers in various states of assembly, 2004]] The AS565 Panther is a twin-engine medium-sized multi-mission rotorcraft. It is capable of performing various naval and land-based missions, such as [[maritime security]], [[search and rescue]] (SAR), [[casualty evacuation]] (CASEVAC), [[vertical replenishment]], [[surveillance]], [[special forces|special forces operation]]s, [[anti-submarine warfare]] (ASW) and [[Anti-surface warfare]] (ASuW). The Panther is powered by a pair of [[Turbomeca Arriel]] [[turboshaft]] engines, which drives the rotorcraft's main rotor as well as the [[fenestron]] anti-torque tail rotor device.[https://www.airbushelicopters.com/website/docs_wsw/pdf/AS565%20MBe/AS565MBe-MP-1214E.pdf "AS565 MBe."] ''Airbus Helicopters'', Retrieved: 8 December 2015.Northham 1987, p. 31. The flight profile of the Panther has been described as being easy to manoeuver, possessing generous [[g-force]] limitations and a high level of stability.Northham 1987, pp. 31–32. In the commando-transport configuration, the Panther may carry up to 10 fully armed soldiers on board at a time in addition to the two pilots flying the aircraft. The main cabin can be rapidly reconfigured to conduct various roles, such as troop-transport, SAR, and MEDIVAC missions; optional equipment includes a full medical suite, [[forward-looking infrared]] (FLIR) camera, emergency flotation, [[loudspeaker]], variable-speed hoist, cargo sling, [[search light]], and a stretcher-support structure. Various avionics are present upon the Panther; some variants are fitted with the advanced human-machine interface (HMI) [[glass cockpit]]. It features the vehicle and engine multifunction display (VEMD), integrated electronic standby instrument (ESI), usage monitoring system (UMS), [[traffic collision avoidance system]] (TCAS), [[terrain awareness and warning system]] (H-TAWS), and dedicated mission display coupled with a multi-sensor processor, a 4-axis [[Aircraft flight control system|automatic flight control system]] (AFCS), [[flight management system]] (FMS), and an advanced [[Radar configurations and types#Detection and search radars|search radar]]. The design of the cockpit and avionics systems, such as the engine management system, provides a high level of automation as part of an effort to reduce workload upon the pilots.Northham 1987, p. 32. The cockpit was deliberately designed with extra panel space to accommodate future upgrades and additional instrumentation that may be installed. The principle element of ASW-configured Panthers is the Helicopter Long-Range Active Sonar (HELRAS), a [[Sonar#Aircraft|dipping sonar]] equipped with a descending array of seven projection elements and a receiving array equipped with eight extending arms, which is capable of detecting submarines up to 500 meters below the water's surface. According to Airbus Helicopters, the Panther family has been qualified to operate from the flight decks of over 100 classes of [[NATO]] vessels, and complies with NATO standardization agreements.[https://www.airbushelicopters.com/website/en/ref/Maritime_66.html "Aircraft: Light and medium helicopters."] ''Airbus Helicopters'', Retrieved: 7 December 2015. The compact size of the Panther has enabled the type to be operated from smaller ocean-going vessels such as [[corvette]]s. To aid in shipboard landings under rough sea conditions and high winds, some variants can be furnished with the hydraulic ''Harpoon'' deck-lock securing device.[https://www.helibras.com.br/wp-content/themes/duesc/extras/pdf/AS565MB.pdf "AS565MB."] ''Helibras'', Retrieved: 8 December 2015. The Panther can be armed with several different sets of munitions and armaments, dependent upon the intended role. Munitions include 20mm pod-mounted [[Cannon#Aircraft use|cannon]]s, 68mm rocket pods, a maximum of eight [[Mistral (missile)|Mistral]] [[air-to-air missile]]s, or a maximum of eight [[HOT (missile)|HOT]] [[anti-tank missile]]s; all of which can be mounted onto a universal weapon support beam. The weapon systems are integrated with a Crouzet HDH-2A electronic sight and the autopilot, the latter of which provides automatic flight handling assistance during weapons deployment to avoid negative tendencies such as nose droop. For improved survivability, the [[radar signature]] is reduced due to the use of [[composite materials]] across the airframe and the use of the fenestron tail rather than a conventional tail rotor; low [[infrared]] paints are also typically applied to the exterior surfaces and jet exhaust dilution devices are installed on the engines to reduce the Panther's infrared signature. Damage resistance is increased by the adoption of [[self-sealing fuel tank]]s and armor-plated crew seating.Northham 1987, p. 30. ==Operational History== {{expand section|date=December 2015}} [[File:US Navy 081116-N-4236E-158 An AS-565MB Panther conducts deck landing qualifications with the multi-purpose amphibious assault ship USS Iwo Jima (LHD 7).jpg|thumb|Panther in flight; note the disc-shaped ASW array under the nose]] The [[French Naval Aviation]] took delivery of 15 Panthers between 1993 and 1998 for maritime operations."Strategic Digest." ''Institute for Defence Studies and Analyses'', 1993. Volume 23, Issues 1–6 p. 157. As a response to increasing acts of [[piracy]] in the [[Gulf of Aden]], since 2008, Panthers have been routinely dispatched upon multiple French frigates that have conducted deployments in support of [[Operation Atalanta]], a long term pan-European counter-piracy operation. In the Aden, the Panther has been typically used for maritime patrol, surveillance and troop-transport missions, such as the transportation of strike teams and the retrieval of detainees.Whittle, Richard. [http://www.aviationtoday.com/regions/usa/High-Sea-Piracy-Crisis-in-Aden_32500.html#.VmYiWcsnyUk "High Sea Piracy: Crisis in Aden."] ''Aviation Today'', 1 June 2009.[http://eunavfor.eu/fs-guepratte-joines-eu-counter-piracy-forces-operation-atalanta/ "FS Guépratte joins EU Counter Piracy Forces Operation Atalanta."] ''European External Action Service'', 25 April 2012.[http://www.nytimes.com/2008/04/11/world/africa/11iht-yacht.4.11921315.html?_r=0 "French troops seize Somali pirates after hostages are freed."] ''The New York Times'', 11 April 2008. In May 2009, France announced a major mid-life upgrade program for the Aeronavale's Panther fleet, focused on cockpit upgrades and improved defensive/offensive equipment. The additions and alterations include a new [[glass cockpit]] compatible with [[night vision goggles]] (NVG), [[electro-optics|electro-optical]] sensors, a new anti-jamming radio, [[Link 11]] data-link, and a self-protection system based on that used on the [[Eurocopter Tiger]].Kieran, Daly. [https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/french-navy-unveils-major-upgrade-for-panther-helico-326794/ "French navy unveils major upgrade for Panther helicopter."] ''Flight International'', 24 May 2009. On 31 May 2011, the first of 16 ''Standard 2'' Panthers was delivered back to the French Navy.Osborne, Tony. [https://www.shephardmedia.com/news/rotorhub/first-panther-standard-2-delivered-to-fr/ "First Panther 'Standard 2' delivered to French Navy."] ''RotorHub'', 38 June 2011. In 1988, the [[Brazilian Army Aviation Command]] took delivery of its first Panther helicopter, which was produced locally by [[Helibras]]. In January 2010, Helibras was awarded a contact to upgrade 34 AS365K Panthers to the new AS365 K2 standard.Hoyle, Craig. [https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/helibras-to-upgrade-brazilian-army-panthers-336976/ "Helibras to upgrade Brazilian army Panthers."] ''Flight International'', 11 January 2010. Changes on the Panther K2 include new [[Turbomeca Arriel|Turbomeca Arriel 2C2CG]] engines which produce 40% more power, a glass cockpit containing new avionics and radio systems, a four-axis autopilot, a new [[weather radar]], NVG-compatibility, and measures to reduce pilot workload, and shall extend the airframe's service life for a further 25 years.Tomkins, Richard. [http://www.upi.com/Business_News/Security-Industry/2014/09/17/Modernization-of-Brazilian-Army-helicopters-to-continue/6431410922403/ "Modernization of Brazilian Army helicopters to continue."] ''United Press International'', 17 September 2014. In March 2014, the first two Panther K2 rotorcraft were delivered to the Brazilian Army.[https://www.airbushelicopters.com/website/en/press/Helibras-begins-deliveries-of-upgraded-AS365-Panther-K2-helicopters-to-the-Brazilian-Army_1427.html "Helibras begins deliveries of upgraded AS365 Panther K2 helicopters to the Brazilian Army."] ''Airbus Helicopters'', 13 March 2014. In September 2014, the Panther K2 passed its technical operation evaluation, having reportedly demonstrated a 98% availability rating throughout the trial period, clearing the way for the full modernisation program to proceed. [[File:IAF-AS-565.jpg|thumb|left|Israeli AS565MA Atalef, 2007]] Following positive experiences of operating a pair of [[Eurocopter HH-65 Dolphin|Aerospatiale SA366G Dauphins]], the [[Israeli Air Force]] opted to procure five AS565MA helicopters, locally designated as ''Atalef''.{{cite book|last=Norton|first=Bill|title=Air War on the Edge – A History of the Israel Air Force and its Aircraft since 1947|publisher=[[Ian Allan Publishing|Midland Publishing]]|year=2004|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=q84hAQAAIAAJ|isbn=1-85780-088-5|location=Surrey, UK|pages=347–349}} Their mission is to extend the naval reach of Israel's defense forces, they can be deployed on board the [[Israeli Navy]]'s [[Sa'ar 5-class corvette]]s when required; the rotorcraft are equipped with long range sensors to identify targets in the [[Mediterranean]] and a datalink to convey sensory data to the corvettes,[https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1994/1994%20-%201466.html "Israel's AS.565 Panther inherits Hellstar sensors."] ''Flight International'', 21 June 1994. p. 18. their combined sensory capability has reportedly helped foil several attempted [[terrorist]] attacks.[https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/long-sighted-178739/ "Long sighted."] ''Flight International'', 9 March 2004. The AS565MA is the only rotorcraft in Israeli service capable of locating people at sea during day or night conditions, and can operate in nearly all sea conditions. During the [[Gulf War]], the [[Royal Saudi Navy]] engaged five [[Iraq]]i patrol boats using a number of Panther helicopters, a total of 15 [[AS 15 TT]] [[Anti-ship missile]]s were fired.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.fr/books?id=l-DzknmTgDUC&pg=PA225 |title=Naval Institute's guide to World naval weapon systems 1997-1998 |first1=Norman |last1=Friedman |editor=Naval Institute press (Annapolis, MD) |year=1997 |pages=224–225 |isbn=1-55750-268-4}} As of 2015, more than 250 navalised variants of the AS 565MB Panther have been in service with operators across 20 nations.[http://www.naval-technology.com/projects/as565-panther/ AS 565MB Naval Variant service notes.] In 2014, the [[Indonesian Navy]] opted to procure 11 ASW-equipped Panthers through [[Indonesian Aerospace]] (PTDI); Airbus Helicopters shall produce the base rotorcraft and deliver them to PTDI's facility in [[Bandung]], [[Indonesia]] and separately install mission systems such as the ASW suite. In the Asian market, the European-built Panther has had limited sales mainly due to export competition from the Chinese-built [[Harbin Z-9]], itself a license-built derivative of the Dauphin alike to the Panther.Waldron, Greg. [http://defense-update.com/20141105_as565mbe.html#.VmXQt8snyUl "Panthers to assume ASW role in Indonesia."] ''Defense Update'', 5 November 2014.[https://www.flightglobal.com/news/articles/indonesian-navy-stalks-as565-panther-deal-398880/ "Indonesian navy stalks AS565 Panther deal."] ''Flight International'', 5 May 2014. ==Variants== [[File:Marina-Panther-Unitasgold2009.jpg|thumb|A [[Naval Infantry Force|Mexican marine]] fast ropes onto the flight deck of [[Berlin-class replenishment ship|''Frankfurt Am Main'']] during a simulated multi-national maritime operation]] [[File:Panther-Meuse.jpg|thumb|The Panther helicopter of {{ship|French frigate|Cassard|D614|2}} transferring a light load to ''[[Durance-class tanker|Meuse]]'']] [[File:Panther-051306-N-9546C-001.jpg|thumb|right|French Navy SA 365 F]] ;SA 365M Panther :Prototype military variant first flown on 29 February 1984.Taylor 1996, pp. 368–370. ;SA 365 FK :Original designation of SA 365 K. ;SA 365 K :The first version of the Panther, based on the AS365 N2. Offered with various armaments, including podded [[M621 cannon|Giat M621]] 20 mm cannon, 2.75 in Forges de Zeebrugge (FZ) rockets (in pods of 19) or 68mm Thales Brandt rockets (in pods of 22). ;AS565 UA :Unarmed military utility variant for reconnaissance, transportation and search and rescue. Can use either Arriel 1M1 or 2C turboshaft engines. ;AS565 UB :Utility version of the AS365 N3, currently in production. This version is powered by two Turbomeca Arriel 2C [[turboshaft]]s, which are equipped with [[FADEC|full authority digital engine control]] (FADEC). The main missions of this version are transport of 8 to 10 fully equipped troops, casualty evacuation and logistic support. ;AS565 AA :Armed military battlefield variant, can be armed with air-to-air weapons including 20-mm canon pods, rockets or up to eight [[Mistral (missile)|Mistral]] air-to-air missiles. Can use either Arriel 1M1 or 2C turboshaft engines. ;AS565 AB :Attack version of the AS365 N3. ;AS565 MA :Multi-purpose unarmed naval variant for maritime patrol, search & rescue (fitted with a hoist) or a surveillance. Can use either Arriel 1M1 or 2C turboshaft engines. ;AS565 MB :Maritime transport and search & rescue version of the AS365 N3. Offered with various armaments, including cabin-mounted 20mm cannon, [[AS 15 TT]] [[anti-ship missile]], [[Mark 46 torpedo]] and Whitehead A.244/S torpedo. ;AS565 SA :Multi-purpose armed naval variant for anti-submarine warfare using either Sonar or MAD, search and rescue and surveillance roles. Can use either Arriel 1M1 or 2C turboshaft engines. ;AS565 SB :Surveillance and ASuW version of the AS365 N3. ;AS565 CA :Armed military anti-armour variant with roof-mounted sight and [[Euromissile HOT|HOT missile]]s. Can use either Arriel 1M1 or 2C turboshaft engines. ;AS565 N3 :Maritime patrol and surveillance version of the AS365 N3 for the [[Hellenic Coast Guard]] ;AS565 SC :Search and rescue version for Saudi Arabia. ;AS565 MBe :Improved MB with an increased payload, Arriel 2N engines and new avionics, initially for the Mexican Navy.{{cite magazine|magazine=[[Flight International]]|title=Enhanced Panther speeds for Mexico|date=11-17 October 2016|page=17|issue=5558|ISSN=0015-3710}} ;HM-1 Pantera :Based on the AS565 AA, manufactured by Airbus Helicopters subsidiary [[Helibras]] for the [[Brazilian Army]].[http://search.janes.com/Search/documentView.do?docId=/content1/janesdata/binder/jhms/jhms5007.htm@current&pageSelected=allJanes&keyword=Eurocopter%20365%20Dauphin&backPath=http://search.janes.com/Search&Prod_Name=JHMS& "Eurocopter AS 365 Dauphin and AS 565 Panther (International)"] [subscription article]. ''Jane's Helicopter Markets and Systems''. Jane's Information Group, 17 March 2011. ;Panther 800 :Version offered for the US Army's Light Utility Helicopter program as a replacement for the [[UH-1 Huey]], with 2 [[LHTEC T800]] turboshafts. Test flown only.[http://www.voughtaircraft.com/heritage/products/html/panther800.html Vought Panther 800 LUH page]"Panther 800 Helicopter." ''Aircraft Engineering and Aerospace Technology'', 1991. p. 8. ;Harbin Z-9 :The [[Harbin Z-9]] and its variants are [[license-built]] by [[Harbin Aircraft Manufacturing Corporation]] for the Chinese [[People's Liberation Army]]. ==Operators== [[File:Eurocopter AS565 Panther Brazilian Army.jpg|right|thumb|Brazilian Army Panther]] ;{{BRA}} *[[Brazilian Army]]{{cite web|url= http://helihub.com/2010/01/07/brazilian-army-upgrades-its-as565k-panther-fleet/ |title= Brazilian Army upgrades its AS565K Panther fleet|publisher= 2012 Helihub.com |date=|accessdate=2 February 2013}} ;{{BUL}} *[[Bulgarian Navy]]{{cite web|url= http://helihub.com/2011/06/21/france-clears-bulgaria-of-obligations-over-last-three-as565-panthers/ |title= France clears Bulgaria of obligations over last three AS565 Panthers|publisher= 2012 Helihub.com |date=|accessdate=2 February 2013}} ;{{FRA}} *[[Aeronavale]]{{cite web|url= http://helihub.com/2011/06/29/first-standard-2-panther-delivered-to-french-navy/|title=First "Standard 2" Panther delivered to French Navy |publisher= Copyright 2009 – 2012 Helihub|date=|accessdate=6 December 2012}} ;{{IDN}} *[[Indonesian Navy]] (3 delivered by November 2016, out of 11 total on order)[http://www.airbushelicopters.com/website/en/press/Airbus-Helicopters-delivers-first-three-AS565-MBe-Panther-to-Indonesia_2046.html ] [[File:Israeli AS565.jpg|thumb|right|[[Israeli Air Force]] AS565 is secured down to the deck of {{USS|Laboon}}]] ;{{ISR}} *[[Israeli Air Force]] (used by the [[Israeli Navy]]){{cite web|url= http://www.airliners.net/photo/Israel---Air/Eurocopter-AS-565MA-Panther/1340347/L/ |title= Aerospatiale- AS565 Panther |publisher=Copyright 2012 Demand Media, Inc |date=|accessdate=6 December 2012}}{{cite web|url= http://www.worldofstock.com/stock-photos/israeli-air-force-helicopter-eurocopter-hh65-dauphin/TRB4238|title=Israeli Air Force Helicopter, Eurocopter HH-65 Dauphin Used by the Israeli Navy. Coming in to Land on a Missile Boat|publisher= 2003-2012 worldofstock.com |date=|accessdate=6 December 2012}} ;{{MEX}} *[[Mexican Navy]]{{cite web|url=http://mxsecurity.wordpress.com/2010/04/16/the-mexican-navy-goes-south/ |title= The Mexican Navy goes south|publisher= |date=|accessdate=2 February 2013}} ;{{MAR}} *[[Royal Moroccan Navy]]{{cite web|url=http://farmorocco.wordpress.com/rmaf-pictures/navy-pictures/ |title= Royal Moroccan Naval fleet |publisher= rmaf.cu |date=|accessdate=2 February 2013}} ;{{UAE}} *[[United Arab Emirates Air Force]]{{cite web|url= http://www.arabaviation.com/AirPower/UnitedArabEmirates.aspx |title=UAE Aircraft Inventory |publisher= arabaviation.com |date=|accessdate=2 February 2013}}{{cite web|url= http://www.airliners.net/photo/United-Arab-Emirates/Aerospatiale-AS-565AA-Panther/0731035/L/&sid=201adc7b0c2908fcc9c5657e3187b3c6| title= Aerospatiale- AS565 Panther |publisher=Copyright 2012 Demand Media, Inc |date=|accessdate=6 December 2012}} ==Specifications (AS365 MB Panther)== [[File:Avionicos_da_Aeronave_HM1_K_2_-_Avia%C3%A7%C3%A3o_do_Ex%C3%A9rcito_.png|thumb|The cockpit of a Panther, 2014]] [[File:Modernização da aeronave HM1 Pantera - Aviação do Exército .png|thumb|Partially assembled Panther, 2014]] {{External media|topic= |width=18% |align=right |video1=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VvNKa_V-32Y French Navy Panther taxiing and taking off] |video2=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=gidEs29QfuM Footage of Panther operations] |video3=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KWuaWGjaNx8 AS565 Panther overview]}} {{Aircraft specs |ref={{citation needed|date=December 2011}} |prime units?=met |crew=1 or 2 pilots |capacity=10 troops |length m=13.68 |height m=3.97 |empty weight kg=2,380 |max takeoff weight kg=4,300 |eng1 number=2 |eng1 name=[[Turboméca Arriel 2C]] |eng1 type=turboshaft |eng1 kw=635 |rot number=1 |rot dia m=11.94 |rot area sqm=111.98 |max speed kmh=306 |farry range main=827 km |endurunce 4.1 hours |range alt=514 mi |ceiling m=5,865 |climb rate ms=8.9 |guns= [[Giat M621]] {{convert|20|mm|in|abbr=on|3}} cannon pods. |rockets= {{convert|68|mm|in|abbr=on|3}} or {{convert|70|mm|in|abbr=on|3}} unguided [[rocket]]s. |missiles=
** Matra [[Mistral missile|Mistral]] air-to-air [[missile]]s. ** [[AS 15 TT]] anti-surface missiles. ** [[Euromissile HOT|HOT]] anti-tank missiles. ** [[Mark 46 torpedo|Mk46]] or Whitehead A.244/S anti-submarine warfare [[torpedo]]es. }} ==See also== {{Portal|Aviation}} {{aircontent |related= * [[Eurocopter AS365 Dauphin]] * [[Eurocopter EC155]] |similar aircraft= * [[AgustaWestland AW159 Wildcat]] * [[Bell 412]] * [[Bell UH-1Y Venom]] * [[Harbin Z-9]] * [[Kaman SH-2G Super Seasprite]] * [[Kamov Ka-27]] * [[Sikorsky SH-60 Seahawk]] * [[Westland Lynx]] |lists= * [[List of rotorcraft]] }} ==References== ===Citations=== {{Reflist|2}} ===Bibliography=== {{refbegin}} * McGowen, Stanley S. "Helicopters: An Illustrated History of Their Impact." ''ABC-CLIO'', 2005. ISBN 1-85109-468-7. * Northham, Hugh. [https://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/1987/1987%20-%201432.html "Panther prowl."] ''Flight International'', 8 August 1987. pp. 30–32. *{{cite book |last=Taylor |first= Michael J. H.|authorlink= |coauthors= |title= Brassey's World Aircraft & Systems Directory|year=1996 |publisher= Brassey's|location= London, England |isbn=1 85753 198 1|pages=}} {{refend}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Airbus Helicopters AS565 Panther}} *[http://www.eurocopter.com/site/FO/scripts/siteFO_contenu.php?mode=&noeu_id=93&lang=EN Eurocopter Company Site – AS 565UB Panther] *[http://www.eurocopter.com/site/FO/scripts/siteFO_contenu.php?mode=&noeu_id=98&lang=EN Eurocopter Company Site – AS 565MB Panther] {{Eurocopter}} {{Sud/Aérospatiale aircraft}} [[Category:Airbus Helicopters aircraft]] [[Category:Fantail helicopters]] [[Category:French military utility aircraft 1980–1989]] [[Category:Military helicopters]] [[Category:French helicopters 1980–1989]] [[Category:Aérospatiale aircraft]]
